entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French vilage, from vil manorial estate, farmstead, from Latin villa

def.dt: :a settlement usually larger than a hamlet and smaller than a town
:something (as an aggregation of burrows or nests) suggesting a village
:a territorial area having the status of a village especially as a unit of local government
:the world viewed as a community in which distance and isolation have been dramatically reduced by electronic media (as television and the Internet)

entry.et: Grigori Potëmkin, who supposedly built impressive fake villages along a route Catherine the Great was to travel

def.dt: :an impressive facade or show designed to hide an undesirable fact or condition
village NE Illinois NW of Chicago pop 34,727
section of New York City in Manhattan on lower W side
